description: Borrowed from French caracole (noun, literally “snail's shell”), caracoler (verb).

entries.meaning: A half-turn performed by a horse and rider in dressage.
(cavalry) A combat maneuver where riders of the same squadron turn simultaneously to their left or to their right.

verbs.description: caracole (third-person singular simple present caracoles, present participle caracoling, simple past and past participle caracoled)

examples: Prince John, upon a grey and high-mettled palfrey, caracoled within the lists at the head of his jovial party, laughing loud with his train, and eyeing with all the boldness of royal criticism the beauties who adorned the lofty galleries.
